item.title: Project Director, Provision of Expertise for the Election Observation Missions
item.author: Penny Buckle
item.description:
This contract does not form part of the BENEF or COM 1 Frameworks but is Lot 1 of the EIDHR Election Framework Contract. However, the expertise required most closely aligns to BENEF Lot 7 expertise, hence we have placed these ‘calls for experts’ on the Lot 7 page of the DAI Framework Contracts website.

EIDHR Election Framework Contract

The scope of Lot 1 of the Framework Contract (FWC) is to provide expertise for the Election Observation Missions (EOMs) in order to provide support to genuine elections in partner countries. As far as the partner countries are concerned, they are in the regions of Africa, Pacific region, Asia, Latin America, North Africa and Middle East countries. The EU normally does not observe in the OSCE area but exceptions to this rule could be considered.

Election observation is a fundamental component of an election process. It is a crucial transparency check that promotes accountability and can therefore deter fraud and irregularities. This in turn can reduce violence and encourage participation. Election observation also provides wider information on a country’s human rights situation and promotes immediate and long-term democratic development.

Since 2000 the European Union (EU) has been committed to undertaking comprehensive, long-term election observation, in accordance with international standards, through the deployment of EOMs.

There is a variety of actors involved in the process:

  • EU Member States (MS) and the European Parliament (EP) are consulted on the selection of election priorities;
  • the Chief Observer is an Member of the European Parliament;
  • EU Member States identify the long and short-term observers;
  • the European Commission is responsible for the budgetary, security and logistical aspects;
  • EU Delegations on the ground are fully involved during the various steps;
  • the European External Action Service (EEAS) is in charge of the programming and political aspects.

EU EOMs are independent (from the EU Member States, the European Commission, the European Parliament) in their political judgements regarding their findings.

On average approximately 10 EU EOMs are deployed yearly to countries all over the world to the destinations mentioned in section 1.1.

EU EOMs are projects financed by the European Commission and implemented through contracting the selected Framework Contract contractor.

EU EOMs are composed of:

  • A Chief Observer (CO), Member of European Parliament designated by the High Representative/Vice-President of the European Commission (HR/VP);
  • Deputy Chief Observer (DCO) contracted by the European Commission as a Special Adviser to the HR/VP;
  • A Core Team (CT) of experts in electoral matters, selected by the European Commission and the EEAS;
  • Long and Short-term Election Observers (LTOs and STOs), volunteers proposed by the Member States (Focal Points) and selected by the European Commission and the EEAS;
  • EP Delegations;
  • Locally recruited Short-term Observers (LSTOs), EU MS diplomats posted in the partner country.

Project Director

As part of the global offer, the tenderer has to identify a Project Director and one substitute, who shall at least be available and formally take over each time the Project Director is temporarily absent. It should be noted that several assignments can run in parallel. The Project Director will have an overall responsibility for the performance of the contract. In particular, the Project Director shall ensure the provision of high-quality services throughout the assignment. The Project Director will also be responsible for the day-to-day management of the contract and act as the central point of contact for each individual assignment.

The Framework Contract Project Director must have the following skills and experience:

Qualifications and skills:

  • University level education in Management, Business Administration, Public Administration, Finance, Economics, International Relations or a related field. Adequate training in a related field and equivalent professional experience in project management may be accepted in lieu of a university degree.
  • Excellent proven command (level C1of English or French, a working knowledge (level B2 of the other language).
  • Knowledge of EU institutions and policies
  • Organisational skills; planning, evaluating and problem-solving skills;
  • Demonstrated ability to work in a multi-cultural environment;
  • Financial and budget management skills;
  • Demonstrated ability to meet tight deadlines and operate under stress situations.

General professional experience

  • At least 10 years of work experience of management, implementation and administration of large-scale international operations in a multi-cultural environment in a similar position, 5 of which in a senior management position.

Specific professional experience

  • Management of large scale international operations or programmes (including with teams in the field);
  • Team management experience;
  • Experience in one or several regions where EU EOMs take place;
  • Management responsibility (contractual, financial, operational) of projects for international organisations, and in particular for EU-funded projects, would be an asset.

The Project Director will have at least the following tasks:

  • responsibility for the day-to-day management of the FWC and each individual assignment;
  • monitoring of the services rendered and of the performance of the experts implementing the individual assignments; ensuring that quality control of the Specific Contract outputs is carried out, either by the Project Director him/herself or through an identified consortium member and its staff.

item.title: 5 Senior Experts in Agro-economy, Agriculture Production Systems, Value Chains, Irrigation Development and Agricultural Finance
item.author: Penny Buckle
item.description:
The global objective of this assignment is to formulate a result and impact oriented sustainable agriculture programme that will support the Government of Malawi (GoM) to enhance food, nutrition and income security.

The objectiveof this consultancy assignment is to provide decision makers in the Government of Malawi and European Commission with sufficient information and analysis to justify the choice of areas and implementation modalities for the KULIMA as a sustainable agriculture programme of the 11th European Development Fund (EDF) for Malawi. In this frame, the overall outcome of the consultancy will be: to provide adequate information which will constitute the basis for concluding a financing agreement between the EU Commission and the GoM to undertake the ambitious transformative sustainable agriculture programme. This will involve the appraisal and strengthening of the design, coherence, relevance, feasibility and potential for effectiveness of a draft action document, along with the elaboration of implementation modalities and the necessary stakeholder collaboration and accountability and coordination arrangements for the implementation of the programme.

The specific objectives of the assignment are to provide advise so that:

  • The choice of areas and implementing modalities proposed in the programme will have a broadbased impact in transforming smallholder homestead diversified farming, increases agriculture production and productivity, contributes to overall improving the nutritional status of Malawians and strengthens value chain development and promotes value addition, ensures easy access to markets and generation of increased incomes for rural households, promotes skills to adapt/mitigate climate change effects, and sustainable management of natural resources in the agriculture sector;
  • Adequate conditions under which EU Aid will have a structural impact in transforming multisector policy and planning, interaction, collaboration and joint operations in addressing food, nutrition and income security in Malawi;
  • The programme design will provide the possibility for EU Member States to join and/or cooperate within an agreed programme, as well as to integrate continental and regional recommendations and country-level concerns and considerations;
  • The programme design will define means and strategies for effective diversification of agriculture production in Malawi;
  • The programme design will ensure that the county / district dimension is taken into consideration.

5 Senior Experts in Agro-economy, Agriculture Production Systems, Value Chains, Irrigation Development and Agricultural Finance

A formulation team of indicatively 5 experts of category I is expected for a total of approximately 210 working days (for both phase 1 and 2).

The proposed Team Leader and key experts covering agroeconomy, agriculture production systems, agriculture value chain development, irrigation development and agricultural finance are preferably to be covered by a category I expert. A combination of expertise can be covered by one expert.

The team is required to have the following general expertise:

  • Team leader with strong ability to lead, coordinate and manage a team to provide high-quality inputs. This requires proven managerial, project management and team coordination skills. (S)He must have been team leader of at least one previous EDF formulation mission for the EU;
  • Up to date knowledge of latest developments in the fields related to the programme, including innovative approaches;
  • All members of the team must have excellent inter-personal and communication skills, including the ability to work with and adjust to diverse audiences (such as politicians, Government technical staff, development partners, civil society, private sector, local chiefs, and smallholder farmers);
  • Within the team there should be knowledge and expertise in organisational capacity development, governance and change management in low-income countries, particularly in relation to agricultural transformation;
  • At least one team member should have experience of working with multi-sectoral programmes, with Governments (at national and sub-national levels, urban and rural), Non-State Actors (e.g. academia, research institutes, private sector including micro-enterprises, farmer organisations, CBOs/CSOs/NGOs; financial institutions) and Development Partners;
  • Within the team there should be expertise in M&E and reporting systems following Project Cycle Management (PCM) logic;
  • At least one team member must be familiar with international policies related to the issues covered by the programme, as well as with EU development policy and EC development cooperation programmes and EU contractual procedures;
  • Experience of similar assignment(s) in Sub-Saharan Africa is an asset.

The formulation team will need the following KULIMA specific expertise:

  • Senior Agro-economist with familiarity of practical participatory approaches.
  • Expertise in extension systems with specialist knowledge and experience in design and implementation of the Farmer Field schools (FFS) approach and farmer Business School (FBS) approach and with experience in support of farmer-led research;
  • Expertise in development of irrigation systems in sub-saharan Africa;
  • Expertise in practical use of integrated production methods (ICM/IPM practices, agroforestry etc…) under tropical and sub-tropical conditions;
  • Expertise on different types of cooperative and farmers' organization development as well as anchor farms and contract farming modalities, preferably in African countries;
  • Thorough knowledge of private sector in agriculture with focused expertise in agriculture value chain development and promotion of micro-, small and medium sized enterprises;
  • Expertise in agriculture related financial service delivery, including formal banking system and other types of financial service providers (e.g. micro-finance, warehouse receipt systems, credit schemes, Village Savings and Loans etc.);
  • Expertise on cross-cutting issues, most particularly nutrition, gender, human rights, social protection and governance must be present in the team.
  • Expertise on trade related issues (domestic and regional) is an asset;
  • Expertise on food safety and food technology, quality assurance, standardization, accreditation and metrology requirements is an asset.

Language and IT skills:

• All team members must have excellent skills in spoken and written English; • All team members must be fully computer-literate.

Education:

Senior Experts (Team Leader and key experts) should have at least a Master’s Degree or equivalent in a discipline relevant to the required expertise of this ToR and to their assignment in the team and 12 years of general professional experience.

Extra years of experience would be acceptable as an alternative to a Master’s Degree. A senior expert (category I) without a Master’s Degree would require relevant professional experience of at least 15 years;

item.description:
The Beyond WTO Program (B-WTO) was developed in response to a request from the Government of Vietnam (GoV) for donor support to help with managing economic integration and the transition to a market economy following WTO accession. The B-WTO goal is “to strengthen government’s capacity to manage the integration of Vietnam into the global economy and the transition of Vietnam to a socialist market economy”. The immediate objective is “implementation of priority policy actions from the GoV’s Action Plan to enhance Vietnam’s capacity to sustain pro-poor growth (GAP)”.

The remit of this project was a review of the 2nd annual work plan’s implementation (AWP2) of Phase 2 of the B-WTO in May 2013. The objectives of the review were to:

  • Evaluate the project implementation performance and project results relative to the logical framework targets and evaluation criteria.
  • Evaluate the results achieved at the Component and Program’s level according to the Monitoring and Evaluation (M&E) framework of the Program.
  • Identify lessons learned from implementation, make recommendations for the remaining duration of the program and the Independent Completion Report process.

item.title: Health Program M&E
item.author: Bryan Schuetz
item.description:
In partnership with the Ministry of Health (MoH), the Australian Government is scoping and piloting a new approach to engagement in the health sector in Timor-Leste. The program approach is innovative in several respects. Key program features are: a systems perspective; joint program oversight by MoH and Australian Government; an emphasis on capacity facilitation through coaching rather than an over-reliance on more traditional technical assistance approaches; ongoing processes of joint intervention design throughout implementation; and rapid cycles of evidence-informed adaptation. These will require significant investments in interactive, exploratory, and rigorous monitoring and evaluation, requiring support from an M&E Specialist that is comfortable with non-traditional M&E approaches.

The Health Program M&E Specialist worked with the Australian Government Timor-Leste Health Team to design an M&E system for Australia’s support to the health sector, that is aligned with the Ministry of Health’s draft Sector M&E Framework and consistent with Australian Aid Program M&E Standards. The primary purpose of the M&E System will be to support strategic management and ongoing improvement of the Australian Government - MoH partnership in the health sector.

item.title: Program 2013 Performance and Quality Mapping Exercise
item.author: Bryan Schuetz
item.description: AusAID’s PNG Program is looking to improve its performance and quality (P&Q) standards and systems. The purpose of this project was to map the PNG Program’s current P&Q capacity and systems, to address the risk of AusAID being unable to demonstrate results for its increased investments in PNG over the next four years. Over the last several years, the PNG Program has undertaken a number of M&E assessments and reviews which have identified key strengths and challenges within the program. This project was intended to pick up where these assessments left off. Through a desk review and consultations with sector teams, the Review Team were to distil key P&Q risks and issues for the PNG Program. The Review Team’s brief included the provision of recommendations on priority activities to support sector approaches to M&E, strengthen the Program’s ability to collect evidence, provide critical analysis and report on results.

item.title: Humanitarian Performance Assessment Framework
item.author: Bryan Schuetz
item.description:
AusAID required a consultant to assist with the development and finalisation of its Humanitarian Performance Assessment Framework. Development of a humanitarian monitoring and evaluation framework is a key commitment outlined in AusAID’s 2011 Humanitarian Action Policy (HAP) and its associated Implementation Plan. In line with the agency focus on results reporting, the HAP and HAP Implementation Plan commit AusAID to develop a monitoring and evaluation framework to support the initial performance assessment framework contained within the HAP and AusAID annual reporting under the Comprehensive Aid Policy Framework.

The key objective of this assignment was to build the Humanitarian program’s capacity for monitoring and reporting results by:

  • In consultation with AusAID’s Humanitarian team, redraft and finalise the Humanitarian Performance Assessment Framework, to ensure it provides a platform to:
  • Track implementation of key commitments in Australia’s 2011 Humanitarian Action Policy; and,
  • Establish a set of measurable humanitarian performance indicators (in addition to the two CAPF indicators) to enable AusAID to track achievements, lessons learned and to report on the results achieved from AusAID’s humanitarian work.

item.title: Review of Pacific Forum Compact Reporting
item.author: Bryan Schuetz
item.description: The purpose of the assignment was to examine country views of aid effectiveness and regional organisations expressed through Forum Compact reporting, particularly peer review of Forum Island Countries’ national development plan processes. The services provided included the preparation of a think piece which outlines key aid effectiveness issues arising from country reporting under the Compact reporting and discusses options for addressing these issues.

item.title: Study on Community-based Social Protection
item.author: Bryan Schuetz
item.description:
Poverty and Social Analysis is the process of using and generating evidence on poverty throughout the aid management cycle. Most poverty and social analysis focuses on economic and human capital, but there are two oft neglected elements: voice and influence, and social capital. Yet more and more development practitioners are recognizing the importance of social capital, particularly informal social capital, in preventing and addressing poverty and vulnerability.

This project supported AusAID to explore:

  • the role of informal social capital in the Fijian context and whether it lends itself to fair redistribution of resources and, if so, the ways in which AusAID can engage with local communities to strengthen existing social capital structures
  • how such structures can enable the disempowered and poor to claim their entitlements in the three domains discussed in the PSA framework
  • the potential challenges that can arise from such efforts. For instance, the poorest are often included on less favorable terms within social networks, and have access to fewer and lower-quality networks. Further, we need to better understand how poverty and disempowerment intersect with an absence of informal social capital, the repercussions this has, and the options available for tackling this.

item.title: Provision of a Child Protection Specialist
item.author: Bryan Schuetz
item.description:
For this project HTSPE was contracted to provide a child protection specialist and handle all the associated management and administrative work.

The child protection specialist provided by HTSPE was required to work on an assignment designed to assist the Pacific Division (PACD) to improve its approach to child protection and managing risks to children. AusAID has a number of partners in the Pacific who work with children or come into contact with children through their activities. The AusAID-wide child protection stocktake, conducted in May 2013 found that there are a number of organisations funded by AusAID in the Pacific with a high or very high inherent child protection risk. Consistent with the stocktake report PACD proposes to escalate efforts to ensure partner organisations policies, procedures and practices are in accordance with AusAID’s Child Protection Policy 2013 and to make child protection a more explicit focus of PACD’s risk management system.
